{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} The '''2012 Ramu violence''' refers to a series of attacks on [[Buddhist]] monasteries, shrines, and houses of Buddhist inhabitants in [[Ramu Upazila]]<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date= |title=Violencia religiosa en Bangladesh por imagen ofensiva publicada en Facebook |url=http://www.bbc.com/mundo/ultimas_noticias/2012/09/120930_ultnot_violencia_religiosa_bangladesh_np |newspaper=BBC Mundo |location= |access-date= }}</ref> in [[Cox's Bazar District]]<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date= 30 September 2012 |title=Desa-desa Buddha di Bangladesh diserang |url=http://www.bbc.com/indonesia/dunia/2012/09/120930_bangaldeshprotest.shtml |newspaper=BBC Indonesia |location= |access-date= }}</ref> in [[Bangladesh]] by local mobs on the midnight past 29 September 2012. The mobs destroyed 12 Buddhist temples and monasteries and 50 houses in reaction to a tagging of an image depicting the [[Quran desecration|desecration of a Quran]] on the timeline of a fake [[Facebook]] account under a Buddhist male name.<ref>{{cite news |date=1 October 2012 |title=Extremists 'linked' |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=251955 |newspaper=The Daily Star |accessdate=3 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=1 October 2012 |title=Khaleda for neutral probe, tough action |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=252012 |newspaper=The Daily Star |accessdate=3 November 2015}}</ref> The actual posting of the photo was not done by the Buddhist who was falsely slandered.<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date=30 September 2012 |title=Bangladesh rampage over Facebook Koran image |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-19780692 |newspaper=BBC News |location= |access-date= }}</ref> The Buddhist was innocent of the accusation.<ref>{{cite news |last= |first= |date= 1 February 2013|title=Bangladesh Buddhists pick up pieces after mob rampage |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-21161354 |newspaper=BBC News |location= Ramu, Cox's Bazar District|access-date= }}</ref> The violence later spread to [[Ukhia Upazila]] in [[Cox's Bazar District]]<ref>{{cite news |date=2 September 2012 |title=5 Buddhist temples attacked in Ukhia |url=http://bdnews24.com/bangladesh/2012/09/30/5-buddhist-temples-attacked-in-ukhia |newspaper=BDNews24 |accessdate=31 May 2013}}</ref> and [[Patiya Upazila]] in [[Chittagong District]] where Buddhist monasteries, Sikh Gurudwaras{{Citation needed|reason=No Gurudwaras are there|date=May 2017}} and Hindu temples were targeted for attacks.
An estimated 25,000 people<ref>{{cite news|date=30 September 2012 |title=Rioting mob torches temples in Bangladesh |author= |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-09-30/rioters-torch-buddhist-temples-in-bangladesh/4288598 |work=ABC News |accessdate=5 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150610055336/http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-09-30/rioters-torch-buddhist-temples-in-bangladesh/4288598 |archivedate=10 June 2015 }}</ref> participated in the violence directed at Buddhists and over 300 people were arrested in connection to the attacks. {{Violence against Buddhists}}
== Background == {{refimprove section|date=May 2016}} An image depicting the desecration of a Quran was posted on the wall of one Uttam Kumar Barua's Facebook profile by an unidentified person using a pseudonym. Coincidentally, Uttam Kumar Barua, a resident of [[Ramu Upazila|Ramu]] in [[Cox's Bazar District]] and an employee of the Bangladesh Small and Cottage Industries, happened to be a Buddhist by faith.
Some local residents took offence to the incident and staged processions and demonstrations in Ramu in the afternoon and evening of 29 September.
== Events ==
On 29 September, at around 10 p.m., a procession was held in Ramu in protest of the perceived blasphemous image uploaded to a Facebook account. Newspaper reports stated that local Awami League leaders were initially seen mobilising the mob and emphasising the sentimental religious issue to counter the opposition. ''[[Daily Star (Bangladesh)|The Daily Star]],'' a widely circulated national daily, reported that a motley group comprising local leaders of pro-Awami League organisations, BNP men, madrasa students and common people were allegedly behind the communal violence at Ramu on Saturday night.<ref>{{cite news |author= Inam Ahmed, Julfikar Ali Manik |date=3 October 2012 |title=A hazy picture appears |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/newDesign/news-details.php?nid=252212 |newspaper=The Daily Star |accessdate=24 October 2012}}</ref> At a subsequent procession, some people demanded the arrest of Uttam Kumar Barua. At around 11:30 p.m., a third procession marched towards Barua Parha, and some of the Buddhist houses were torched.<ref name="bdnews2430092012">{{cite news|date=30 September 2012 |title=Buddhist temples, homes burned, looted in Ramu |url=http://bdnews24.com/details.php?id=233354&cid=2 |newspaper=bdnews24.com |accessdate=3 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121105180958/http://bdnews24.com/details.php?id=233354&cid=2 |archivedate=5 November 2012 }}</ref> Subsequently, Buddhist temples, monasteries, and residences were also torched. Ten Buddhist villages were attacked as well with<ref name="bdnews2430092012"/> gunpowder, kerosene, and petrol used for the purpose.<ref>{{cite news |title=Ramu Violence: Home Minister points finger at MP |author= |url=http://bdnews.com/10508 |newspaper=''BDNEWS'' |date=30 September 2012 |accessdate=3 October 2012}}</ref> The arson continued till 3 a.m. 30 September.
On 30 September, in the evening, Buddhist monasteries and Hindu temples were vandalized in [[Ukhia Upazila]] in [[Cox's Bazar District]].<ref name="ds02102012">{{cite news |title=166 nabbed for Ramu rampage |author= |url=http://www.daily-sun.com/index.php?view=details&archiev=yes&arch_date=02-10-2012&type=Tense-Georgia-goes-to-polls&pub_no=279&cat_id=1&menu_id=1&news_type_id=1&news_id=58542 |newspaper=Daily Sun |date=2 October 2012 |accessdate=2 October 2012}}</ref> Two more Buddhist monasteries were burnt in [[Ukhia Upazila|Ukhiya]] early on Monday. At Marichya, the Dipankar Bouddha Bihar was torched while at Khairatipara the Pangyamitra Bouddha Bihar was also torched. By Monday, a total of six monasteries and temples have been damaged in [[Ukhia Upazila|Ukhia]].<ref name="na02122012">{{cite news |title=Mobs torch two more monasteries in Cox's Bazar |last1=Juberee |first=Abdullah |last2=Atikuzzaman |first2=A.K.M. |url=http://www.newagebd.com/detail.php?date=2012-10-02&nid=25668#.UGx7q2Hx3dc |newspaper=New Age |date=2 October 2012 |accessdate=2 October 2012}}</ref> The fanatics also burnt the Matri Mandir Hindu temple in Jelepara.<ref name="achr">{{cite press release |title=24 Buddhist and Hindu temples burnt in Bangladesh - India and UN urged to intervene |url=http://www.achrweb.org/press/2012/IND08-2012.html |publisher=Asian Centre for Human Rights |date=1 October 2012 |accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref> The participants burned religious texts and seized Buddha statues.<ref>{{cite news |last=Ethirajan |first=Anbarasan |date= 1 February 2013 |title=Bangladesh Buddhists pick up pieces after mob rampage |url=http://beta.bbc.com/news/world-asia-21161354 |newspaper=BBC News |location=Ramu, Cox's Bazar District |access-date= }}</ref>
The violence spread to [[Patiya Upazila]] in [[Chittagong District]] on Sunday. At noon, Buddhist monasteries and Hindu temples were attacked in [[Patiya Upazila|Patiya]].<ref name="ds02102012"/> After the midnight past Sunday i.e. on the early morning of 1 October 500 workers of the Western Marine shipping company torched two Buddhist monasteries and one Hindu temple in [[Patiya Upazila|Patiya]]. In Kalagaon, the Ratnankur Bouddha Bihar and the Nabarun Sangha Durgabari were torched as was the Abhay Bouddha Bihar in Lakhera.<ref name="na02122012"/>
[[Rohingya]] refugees from [[Myanmar]] are suspected to be involved in the attacks. On Tuesday afternoon, 2 October, three Rohingyas were arrested by the police in [[Chakaria Upazila]] of [[Cox's Bazar District]] while they were trying to attack a Buddhist monastery in Manikpur.<ref name="ds03102012">{{cite news |title=3 Rohingyas held in Cox's Bazar |author= |url=http://www.daily-sun.com/index.php?view=details&type=daily-sun-news&pub_no=280&cat_id=1&menu_id=0&news_type_id=3&news_id=58912 |newspaper=Daily Sun |date=3 October 2012 |accessdate=3 October 2012}}</ref>
== Investigation == On 30 September, an official inquiry committee was constituted and headed by Nurul Islam, the Additional Divisional Commissioner of [[Chittagong Division]]. It sat on 1 October and reviewed the reports of the Upazila Nirbahi Officers of the troubled upazilas and the daily newspaper reports.<ref name="na02122012"/>
The Supreme Court on 12 May 2014 directed Tofail Ahmed, upazila chairman of Naikhangchhari upazila of [[Bandarban]], to surrender before a lower court in four weeks in connection with the attack and vandalisation of a Buddhist temple at Ramu in Cox's Bazar in 2012. Tofail is the prime suspect in the Ramu incident according to a governmental investigation report.<ref>{{cite web|title=SC cancels key Ramu attacker's bail|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/sc-cancels-key-ramu-attacker-s-bail-23781|publisher=The Daily Star}}</ref>
== Reactions == Groups of Buddhist monks and Hindu groups in [[Burma]],<ref name="scotsman06">{{cite news |title=Burmese Buddhists protest attacks|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/international/burmese-buddhists-protest-attacks-1-2564496 |newspaper=The Scotsman|date=6 October 2012 |accessdate=6 October 2012}}</ref> [[India]],<ref name="ntindia">{{cite web|title=Buddhists, Hindus in Tripura protest against attack on Bangladesh temples|url=http://www.newstrackindia.com/newsdetails/2012/10/09/304-Buddhists-Hindus-in-Tripura-protest-against-attack-on-Bangladesh-temples.html|publisher=News Track India|date=9 October 2012 |accessdate=9 October 2012}}</ref> [[Sri Lanka]],<ref name="afpsl">{{cite press release |title=Bangladesh embassy stoned during monks' protest|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5g8nZp3tP4dOWk6ihAjeHwOs_HV3A?docId=CNG.371bcd8a8b07dc52361e0f3c68a4924f.7f1|publisher=Agence France-Presse|date=4 October 2012 |accessdate=6 October 2012}}</ref> and [[Thailand]]<ref name="afpsl"/> demonstrated in response to the anti-Buddhist violence in Bangladesh. In [[Colombo, Sri Lanka]], some protested outside the Bangladeshi embassy and a petition was delivered condemning the attacks.
Some windows of the Bangladeshi embassy in Colombo, Sri Lanka were vandalized before police arrived and dispersed the protest.<ref name="afpsl"/>
On 6 October, Bangladeshi Prime Minister [[Sheikh Hasina]] condemned the anti-Buddhist violence, stated her belief that it was premeditated, and urged restraint over the issue.<ref name="asiantribune">{{cite news |title=Attack on Buddhist Temples premeditated: Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina|url=http://www.asiantribune.com/news/2012/10/06/attack-buddhist-temples-premeditated-prime-minister-sheikh-hasina|newspaper=Asian Tribune|date=7 October 2012 |accessdate=7 October 2012}}</ref>
On 8 October the Prime Minister herself visited the affected areas and condemned the incident while promising proper justice.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bdnews24.com/details.php?id=233917&cid=2|title=PM visits Ramu, meets victims|date=8 October 2012 |newspaper=bdnews24.com |accessdate=8 October 2012}}</ref>
Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina directed Bangladesh Army to rebuild these temples under a project, titled 'Rebuilding and Renovation of damaged Buddhist Temples', spending Tk 200 million. The Bangladesh Army rebuilt and renovated these Buddhist temples and Bihars in 19 separate places incorporating the traditional designs of the renowned architects from the Buddhist community.<ref name=BSS>{{cite news |date=10 March 2014 |title=President visits rebuilt Buddhist temples in Ramu |url=http://www.bssnews.net/newsDetails.php?cat=0&id=395089&date=2014-03-10 |newspaper=Bangladesh Sangbad Sangstha (BSS) |accessdate=6 June 2014}}</ref>
President of Bangladesh Abdul Hamid on 10 January 2014 visited several rebuilt Buddhist temples and centers at Ramu upazila of Cox's Bazar.During the visit, president enquired about the wellbeing of local Buddhist community and distributed cheques to the affected members of the community.<ref name=BSS/>

{{Infobox Christian leader | honorific-prefix = Most Reverend | name = Anthony Alwyn Fernandes Barreto | honorific-suffix = | title = [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Sindhudurg|Bishop of Sindhudurg]] | image = | image_size = | caption = | archdiocese = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Goa and Daman|Goa and Daman]] | diocese = [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Sindhudurg|Sindhudurg]] | appointed = 5 July 2005 | enthroned = | ended = | predecessor = | successor = ''Incumbent'' | other_post = Chairman Youth Commission in Western Regions Bishops Conference | ordination = 13 October 1979 | ordained_by = Bishop Valerian D’Souza | consecration = 5 Oct 2005 | consecrated_by = [[Pedro López Quintana]] | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1952|12|22|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Goa]] [[India]] | death_date = | death_place = | buried = | nationality = [[India]]n | religion = [[Roman Catholic]] | residence = Bishop's House, Kankavli District Sindhudurg - 416 602 Maharastra, India | parents = | spouse = | children = | occupation = | previous_post = Dean of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Poona | profession = | alma_mater = | signature = | coat_of_arms = | motto = GROW INTO THE FULLNESS OF CHRIST }} '''Bishop Anthony Alwyn Fernandes Barreto'''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/topic/anthony-alwyn-fernandes-barreto|title=Anthony Alwyn Fernandes Barreto News, Latest Breaking News on Anthony Alwyn Fernandes Barreto {{!}} Daily News & Analysis|website=dna|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-11}}</ref> is the serving Bishop of the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Sindhudurg]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://apostolicnunciatureindia.com/?page_id=7&listpage=2&instance=1|title=Apostolic Nunciature, India » Bishops of India|website=apostolicnunciatureindia.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-09-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/sind0.htm#3415|title=Diocese of Sindhudurg, India|work=GCatholic|access-date=2017-09-11}}</ref>.
== Early Life == He was born in [[Goa]], [[Daman and Diu Portuguese|Daman and Diu]] on 22 December 1952<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bookdepository.com/Anthony-Alwyn-Fernandes-Barreto-Jules-Reene/9786138686989|title=Anthony Alwyn Fernandes Barreto : Jules Reene : 9786138686989|last=Depository|first=Book|website=www.bookdepository.com|language=en|access-date=2017-09-11}}</ref>.
== Priesthood == He was Ordained a Catholic Priest on 13 October 1979 by Bishop Valerian D’Souza.
== Episcopate == He was Appointed Bishop of [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Sindhudurg]] on 5 July 2005 and Ordained on 5 Oct 2005 by [[Pedro López Quintana]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/bishop/bfebar.html|title=Bishop Anthony Alwyn Fernandes Barreto [Catholic-Hierarchy]|last=Cheney|first=David M.|website=www.catholic-hierarchy.org|access-date=2017-09-10}}</ref>. Before becoming a bishop he has served as the Dean in the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Poona]]. He chairs the Youth Commission in Western Regions Bishops Conference<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ucanindia.in/diocesan-directory/indian/bishop/anthony-alwyn-fernandes-barreto/91|title=Anthony Alwyn Fernandes Barreto {{!}} Bishop {{!}} Diocesan Directory {{!}} UCAN India|website=www.ucanindia.in|access-date=2017-09-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://directory.ucanews.com/bishops/bishop-fernandes-barreto/197|title=Bishop Anthony Alwyn Fernandes Barreto {{!}} Bishop of Sindhudurg Diocese Anthony Alwyn Fernandes Barreto {{!}} Ucanews|website=directory.ucanews.com|access-date=2017-09-10}}</ref>.

The '''Bahá'í Faith in Cameroon''' was established when the country was separated into two [[colonies]] - [[Cameroons|British]] and [[Cameroun|French Cameroon]]. The first [[Bahá'í Faith|Bahá'í]] in [[Cameroon]] was [[Enoch Olinga]], who had left his homeland of [[Uganda]] to bring the religion to British Cameroon in 1953. Meherangiz Munsiff, a young [[Non-resident Indian and person of Indian origin|Indian]] woman who had moved from [[Bahá'í Faith in the United Kingdom|Britain]], arrived in French Cameroon April 1954 - both Olinga and Munsiff were honoured with the title [[Knight of Bahá'u'lláh]].<ref name="uk">{{Cite news | last = Mughrab | first = Jan | title = Jubilee Celebration in Cameroon | periodical = Bahá'í Journal of the Bahá'í Community of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland | volume=20 | issue=5 | year = 2004 | url =http://bahai-library.com/pdf/bjuk/bjuk_2004_jan-feb_v20_n5_7_Jubilee_Celebration_in_Cameroon.pdf}}</ref> In 2003 Bahá'ís estimated there were 40,000 adherents of the religion in the country.<ref name="bud">{{Cite news | author = Bahá'í International Community| title = Cameroon celebrates golden time | newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service| date = 2003-09-23 | url = http://news.bahai.org/story/249 }}</ref> The [[Association of Religion Data Archives]] (relying on [[World Christian Encyclopedia]]) estimated about 50800 Bahá'ís in 2005.<ref name="WCE-05">{{cite web| title = Most Baha'i Nations (2005) | work = QuickLists > Compare Nations > Religions > | publisher = The Association of Religion Data Archives | year = 2005| url =http://www.thearda.com/QuickLists/QuickList_40c.asp | accessdate = 2009-07-04}}</ref>
==Early history==
[[File:Cameroon boundary changes.PNG|left|thumb|250px]]
In 1953, [[Shoghi Effendi]], the head of the Bahá'í Faith, planned an international teaching plan termed the [[Ten Year Crusade]]. This was during a period of wide scale growth in the religion across [[Sub-Saharan Africa]] near the end of the period of the [[Colonisation of Africa]].<ref name="UofC">{{cite web |title=Overview Of World Religions |work=General Essay on the Religions of Sub-Saharan Africa |publisher=Division of Religion and Philosophy, [[University of Cumbria]] |url=http://philtar.ucsm.ac.uk/encyclopedia/sub/geness.html |accessdate=2008-04-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071209082606/http://philtar.ucsm.ac.uk/encyclopedia/sub/geness.html |archivedate=2007-12-09 }}</ref> During the plan [[Ali Nakhjavani]] and his wife drove by car with two African [[Pioneering (Bahá'í)|pioneers]] from [[Bahá'í Faith in Uganda|Uganda]] where the religion was growing very quickly<ref name="survey">{{Cite journal | last = Smith | first = Peter | authorlink = Peter Smith (Bahá'í) | last2 = Momen | first2 = Moojan | author2-link = Moojan Momen | title = The Baha'i Faith 1957-1988: A Survey of Contemporary Developments | journal = Religion | volume = 19 | issue = 01 | pages = 63–91 | year = 1989 | url = http://bahai-library.com/momen_smith_developments_1957-1988 | doi = 10.1016/0048-721X(89)90077-8 }}</ref> to open new countries to the religion. The first pioneer in the region was Max Kinyerezi October 6<ref name="BN277">{{cite magazine | title = World Crusade Report; Virgin Goal Areas |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1954 |pages=6–7 | url = | issue = 277}}</ref> who settled in what was then [[French Equatorial Africa]], and then Enoch Olinga to British Cameroon<ref name="uk" /> on October 15.<ref name="BN277" /> In [[Limbe, Cameroon|Limbe]] (then called Victoria), through the efforts of Olinga, Jacob Tabot Awo converted to the religion becoming the first Cameroonian Bahá'í. During the following year there were many converts to the religion, many of whom were from the [[Basel Mission]] system of Protestant Christians.<ref>{{cite web | last = Lee | first = Tony | title = Conversions to the Baha'i Faith in Uganda | work = Research Notes in Shaykhi, Babi and Baha'i Studies, No. 5 (August, 1997) | publisher = H-NET List for Bahai Studies at h-net.msu.edu | date = 1997-06-25 | url = http://www.h-net.org/~bahai/notes/uganda1.htm | accessdate = 2008-03-29 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080509100400/http://www.h-net.org/~bahai/notes/uganda1.htm| archivedate= 9 May 2008 | deadurl= no}}</ref> Meherangiz Munsiff, a young [[Bahá'í Faith in India|Indian]] woman, arrived in [[Cameroons|French Cameroon]] in April 1954 in [[Douala]] after helping to found the Bahá'í Faith in [[Madagascar]].<ref name="bud" /><ref>{{Cite news | author = Bahá'í International Community | title = Four islands unite in celebrations | newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service | date = 2004-03-29 | publisher = Bahá'í International Community | url = http://news.bahai.org/story/288 }}</ref> A letter from Olinga describes the advancement of the religion into 6 towns and translation work into the [[Duala language]] had begun of a pamphlet.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Letter from Baha'i Brother in Africa |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1954 | page =10 | url = | issue = 280}}</ref>
As the number of Bahá'ís was growing rapidly, Shoghi Effendi asked if members of the religion could pioneer to neighboring areas where there were still no Bahá'ís.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = African Teaching |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1954 | page =21 | url = | issue = 280}}</ref> On April 21, 1954 a Bahá'í [[Local Spiritual Assembly]] was formed and five young Cameroonians left during the [[Ridván]] period,<ref name="BN283">{{cite magazine | title = United States Africa Teaching Committee; Goals for this year |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1954 |pages=10–11 | url = | issue = 283}}</ref> each becoming a Knight of Bahá'u'lláh; the various protectorates they arrived in merged into the modern countries of Cameroon, [[Ghana]], and [[Togo]].<ref name="bud" /> It was emphasized that western pioneers be self-effacing and focus their efforts not on the colonial leadership but on the native Africans<ref name="BN283" /> - and that the pioneers must show by actions the sincerity of their sense of service to the Africans in bringing the religion and then the Africans who understand their new religion are to be given freedom to rise up and spread the religion according to their own sensibilities and the pioneers to disperse or step into the background.<ref name="BN283" /> Enoch Olinga is specifically mentioned as an example of this process unfolding as he arose out of Uganda and repeated the quick growth of the religion. Because of the successive waves of people becoming Knights of Bahá'u'lláh, Enoch Olinga was entitled "Abd'l-Futuh", a Persian name meaning "the father of victories" by Shoghi Effendi.<ref name="bud" /> In very early 1955, Valerie Wilson, an Auxiliary Board member for Africa stationed in Monrovia, Liberia, embarked on what was considered a bold trip for a woman alone by car to travel on a trip across some {{convert|2000|mi|km|sigfig=1|order=flip}} to visit the Bahá'í groups functioning in the Gold Coast, Togoland and the British Cameroons.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Pioneering Letters Reflecting Quickening of Spiritual Growth; Lomé, French Togoland|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1954 | page =6 | url = | issue = 281}}</ref> In April 1955 British Cameroon had eight assemblies.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = world Crusade; New Assemblies in Africa |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1955 | page =5 | url = | issue = 283}}</ref>
==Growth==
In 1956 a regional Bahá'í [[National Spiritual Assembly]] of North West Africa was elected with Olinga as the chairman with its seat in [[Tunis]], comprising areas from the Cameroons north to [[Tunisia]] and parts west including Islands like the [[Canary Islands]].<ref>{{Cite web | first = N. Richard | last = Francis |title=Olinga, Enoch | year = 1998 |website=Bahá'í Library |url=http://bahai-library.com/francis_olinga_biography}}</ref> Early in 1957 the Bahá'ís in British Cameroon acquired a center<ref>{{cite magazine | title = International News; Central and East Africa; Haziratu'l-Quds Acquired in Victoria |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1957 | page =13 | url = | issue = 316}}</ref> and the population was noted at some 300 Bahá'is while the younger community of French Cameroon had between 10 and 20 Bahá'ís and there was a Bahá'í conference on the progress of the religion held in [[Tiko|Mutengene]], near Tiko.<ref>{{cite book | last = Effendi | first = Shoghi | title = Messages to the Bahá’í World: 1950–1957 | publisher = US Bahá’í Publishing Trust | edition = 1971 | year = 1973 | pages = 113–115 | url = http://reference.bahai.org/en/t/se/MBW/mbw-54.html#pg113 | isbn = 0-87743-036-5}}</ref> In 1958 the Bahá'ís of Cameroon sent another pioneer, Willie Enang, to Ghana<ref>{{cite magazine | title = N.W. Africa Reports Enrollments, Formation of New Assemblies; Nigerian and Cameroons |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1958 |pages=17–18 | url = | issue = 316}}</ref> while multiple communities held local conferences on the progress of the religion in their area.<ref>{{cite magazine | title =First Photographs From British Cameroons Illustrate Results of Continuous Teaching By Regional Committee and Local Assemblies|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1958 | page =7 | url = | issue = 333}}</ref> Bahá'ís sometimes walked through dense forests to people who had not heard of Jesus Christ.<ref>{{cite magazine | title =Two Traveling Teachers Visit Remote Villages in Dense Forests of Southern Cameroons|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1960 | page =14 | url = | issue = 348}}</ref> By 1960 the entire Bahá'í population across North West Africa was 3000 and 1800 were in British Cameroon.<ref>{{cite magazine | title =New Victories Announced at World Center |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1960 |pages=1–2| url = | issue = 354}}</ref> Limbe, (then called Victoria), British Cameroon, hosted the convention for the election of the regional national assembly for north west Africa in 1960 and there were 45 delegates, including local chiefs and women, as well as Enoch Olinga.<ref>{{cite magazine | title =National Conventions Recount Growth of Faith; Northwest Africa|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1960 |pages=14–15 | url = | issue = 354}}</ref> Enoch Olinga could not attend the dedication of the [[Bahá'í House of Worship]] in his native Uganda because of [[History of Cameroon#Cameroon after independence|political turmoil in Cameroon]] after independence.<ref name="BN361">{{cite magazine | title = Hand of Cause 'Amatu'l-Baha Ruhiyyih Khanum Dedicates Mother Temple of Africa |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1961 |pages=1–9 | url = | issue = 361}}</ref> While over 1500 people and Bahá'ís from many places in Africa went, Olinga preferred to stay in Cameroon to help guide the Bahá'ís through times of civil unrest.
By 1963 the following cities in Cameroon had Bahá'í communities:<ref>{{cite book| author = Hands of the Cause Residing in the Holy Land | title = The Bahá'í Faith: 1844-1963, Information Statistical and Comparative, Including the Achievements of the Ten Year International Bahá'í Teaching & Consolidation Plan 1953-1963 | publisher = Peli - P.E.C. Printing World LTD. Ramat Gan | year = 1964 | location = Israel | pages = 10, 21, 22, 25, 42, 43, 47, 69, 82| url = http://bahai-library.com/handscause_statistics_1953-63}}</ref>
; Local Spiritual Assemblies in Cameroon:
{| class="wikitable" |- | Ashum | Atibon | [[Bakebe]] | Bakogo | Bangapongo | Bara | Batchuakagbe | Batchuntai | Bekume | Boa | [[Buea]] |- | [[Douala]] | Defang | Ebeagwa | Ebinsi | Ebonji | Edjuingang | Eshobi | Etoko | Eyang | Faitok | Fotabe |- | Kembong | Kombone | [[Kumba]] | Mambo | [[Mamfe]] | Mbatop | Mbehetok | Mbinjong | Moliwe | Molyko | Muambong |- | Mukonyo | Mutengene | [[Muyuka]] | Nchemba | Nfontem | Ngassang | Ngombuku | Nguti | Ntenembang | Nyang | Ossing |- | Sabes | Sumbe | Takpa | Takwai | Tali | [[Tiko]] | Tinto (1) | Tinto (2) | Tintombu | Tombel | Victoria ([[Limbe, Cameroon|Limbe]]) |}
; Bahá'í groups (between 1 and 9 individuals):
{| class="wikitable" |- | [[Bamenda]] | Bato | Besongabang | Ekona |- | Ekpaw | Marumba | Mpundu | Tayor |}
; Isolated individuals:
{| class="wikitable" |- | Bomono | Dibombari | Ebensuk | Melkai |- | Moanjo | Ndekwai | [[Nsoke]] | [[Yaoundé]] |}
Later October 1963 at a large public meeting in Belgium the ambassador to Belgium from the Republic of Cameroons was a guest at a Bahá'í observance of [[United Nations Day]].<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Cameroons Ambassador Attends Belgian World Religion Day Commemoration |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1964 | page =9 | url =http://bahai-news.info/viewer.erb?vol=05&page=798 | issue = 397}}</ref>
===Regionalization issues===
And in 1963 the Cameroons were re-organized under the regional national assembly system to be with the West-Central African National Assembly.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = The Second Annual Convention for the Baha'is of West Central Africa… |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1964 | page =15 | url = | issue = 397}}</ref> The second convention was held in Limbe - and that year its members were Stephen Tabe, Sampson Forchnk, Janet Mughrabi, Moses Akombi, Lillie Rosenberg, Oscar Njang, Jawad Mughrabi and Solomon Tanyi and Sherman Rosenberg. The convention of 1966 for the west central regional national assembly was held in [[Mamfe]].<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Enoch Olinga Inspires West Central Africa Convention |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1966 | page =6 | url = | issue = 425}}</ref> Following the death of Shoghi Effendi, the elected [[Universal House of Justice]] was head of the religion and began to re-organized the Bahá'í communities of Africa by splitting off national communities to form their own National Assemblies from 1967 though the 1990s.<ref name="history">{{cite web |author=National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of South Africa |title=Bahá'ís in South Africa - Progress of the Bahá'í Faith in South Africa since 1911 |work=Official Website |publisher=National Spiritual Assembly of the Bahá'ís of South Africa |year=1997 |url=http://www.bahai.org.za/cm/node/19 |accessdate=2008-03-19 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080408202119/http://www.bahai.org.za/cm/node/19 |archivedate=8 April 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In the presence of Hand of the Cause William Sears<ref name="BN439">{{cite magazine | title = Cameroon Republic Elects National Assembly - Wins New Goals|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1967 |pages=2–3 | url = | issue = 439}}</ref> in 1967 the National Spiritual Assembly (NSA) of the Bahá'ís of Cameroon was elected for the first time thus splitting the country off from the regional National Assembly established in 1956<ref name="bud" /> and had jurisdiction over neighboring areas of Spanish Guinea, Fernando Po, Cariseo and São Tomé and Príncipe Islands while the rest of the west central regional assembly continued over other countries.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = West Central African National Assembly Incorporates|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1967 |pages=4–5 | url = | issue = 434}}</ref> In 1967 the Bahá´ís of Cameroon initiated a proclamation project in Spanish territories of Fernando Poo and Rio Muni.<ref name="BN442" />
In December 1971 Cameroon hosted the first regional African youth conference in Yaounde.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Central African Youth Conference|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1969 | page =13/24 | url = | issue = 464}}</ref> Bus loads and cars of youth came from Chad and the Central African Republic, including youth visiting from the Philippines, Malaysia, India, Iran, Canada and the United States then in Chad and Cameroon for a period of service to the community came - during the conference two radio interviews were given. Book exhibits were held in 1974 in the University in Yaounde and a classroom in the Pan-African Institute of the Buea which also attracted radio coverage.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Cameroon Republic; Book displays proclaim Faith|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1975 | page =6 | url = | issue = 526}}</ref> In 1978 an international Bahá'í youth Conference was held in Cameroon with 380 attendees from some 19 countries.<ref name="basic">{{cite book |author=Cameron, G. |author2=Momen, W. |year= 1996 |title= A Basic Bahá'í Chronology |publisher= George Ronald |location=Oxford, UK |isbn= 0-85398-404-2 |page = 416 }}</ref>
Though he had recently toured Cameroonian in 1975<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Cameroon Republic; Mr. Olinga delighted with 10-day tour|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1975 |pages=6–7 | url = | issue = 536}}</ref> in December 1979 a full account of the circumstances under which [[Knight of Bahá'u'lláh]] for Cameroon, [[Hand of the Cause]], [[Enoch Olinga]] had been murdered Sept. 16th 1977 in Uganda during political and social turmoil. Final answers may never be known why he and most of his family were murdered with confidence.<ref name="BN585">{{cite magazine| title = The Hand of the Cause of God Enoch Olinga 'The Father of Victories'|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1979 |issn=0195-9212 | page =15 | url = | issue = 585}}</ref> A biography published in 1984 examined his impact in Cameroon and beyond.<ref>{{cite magazine| title = Enoch Olinga: The pioneering years|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=May 1984 |issn=0195-9212 |pages=4–9 | url = | issue = 638}}</ref> The first person in Cameroon to join the religion withstood beatings to persevere in his choice. The first woman to become a Bahá'í in Cameroon did so from his impact on her life though she had been an active Christian before - both she and her husband converted and were among the first to move to Togo and then Ghana. Another early Bahá'í, the first of the Bamiliki tribe, moved to what was then French Cameroon to help there. Another early contact joined the religion later but his wife was the first Bahá'í of Nigeria. The researcher again found that there was an emphasis not on rooting out cultural traditions among the peoples but instead focusing on awareness of the religion and awareness of scientific knowledge should not relate to social class. There were accusations of political intrigue of which Olinga was acquitted. It was judged that Olinga was always sincere and never belittled.
In 1982 the first Bahá'í under the assigned region to Cameroon of Fernando Po joined the religion.<ref name="BN617">{{cite magazine| title = Around the World; Cameroon|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1982 |issn=0195-9212 | page =12 | url = | issue = 617}}</ref> Joseph Sheppherd was a pioneer to Cameroon and Equatorial Guinea, circumstances woven into a book he later wrote which presents the Bahá'í Faith in a context of global change (see [[Bahá'í Faith in fiction]]) and delves into the dynamics of pioneering as a method to gain understanding of spiritual issues compared to social issues, to struggle with a cultural naivete, which was published in ''Bahá'í News'' in December 1988.<ref>{{cite magazine| title = Around the World; Cameroon|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1982 |issn=0195-9212 |pages=2–4 | url = | issue = 693}}</ref>
===Intranational developments===
In 1967 local assemblies began to acquire or build local centers<ref name="BN439" /> as one of many activities of the community some of which continued into 1968. Informational packets and interviews were granted to major print and radio news outlets and coverage of events continued.<ref name="BN449">{{cite magazine | title = Cameroon Convention Sparks Active Discussion |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1968 | page =12 | url = | issue = 449}}</ref>
In October 1967 the Bahá'ís of Cameroon were included in efforts, and multiplied instances of, observances of [[United Nations Day]] across Cameroon including talks given by [[Hand of the Cause]] [[Rúhíyyih Khanum]].<ref name="BN442">{{cite magazine | title = First U.N. Observances in Cameroon Republic|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1968 |pages=16–17 | url = | issue = 442}}</ref> In November Rúhíyyih Khanum dedicated the first school in the Cameroons which was dedicated first to classes studying the religion,<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Cameroon Republic Dedicates First Teaching Institute|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1968 | page =15 | url = | issue = 434}}</ref> (the first classes were held in December 1968.)<ref>{{cite magazine | title =Teaching Institute of Cameroon Republic |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1968 | page =6 | url = | issue = 457}}</ref> The convention of 1968 had 45 delegates and an observer from Fernando Po island.<ref name="BN449" /> The NSA of the country wrote a document, ''Declaration of Loyalty to Government'', possibly dated from 1968, which declares the loyalty of the institution to the government of the country.<ref name="MacEoin">{{cite web | last = MacEoin | first = Denis |author2=William Collins | title = Principles | work = The Babi and Baha'i Religions: An Annotated Bibliography | publisher = Greenwood Press's ongoing series of Bibliographies and Indexes in Religious Studies | url = http://bahai-library.com/books/biblio/principles.html | accessdate = 2008-03-26}}</ref> But in 1969 large regions of Cameroon were still sparely populated,<ref>{{cite magazine | title =Teaching Journey Under Nigerian Skies |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1970 | page =6 | url = | issue = 467}}</ref> while the first school in eastern, formerly French, Cameroon had its first meeting in spring 1969.<ref>{{cite magazine | title =Cameroon |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1969 | page =15 | url = | issue = 464}}</ref> In 1977 a mobile school was established run from a van which toured for several months in 1977 visiting villages and farms.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Cameroon Republic; Mobile van helps educate villages|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1975 | page =17 | url = | issue = 559}}</ref> In 1978 three regional conferences were held. A conference on the progress of the religion at which it was announced there was an estimated 166 assemblies, 27 of which and established permanent centers, and beyond that some 832 towns and places Bahá'ís lived in Cameroon.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Cameroon Republic; Localities goal near|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1975 | page =12 | url = | issue = 564}}</ref> A women's regional conference gathered 30 women at the national center and eighty Bahá'í gathered for a regional conference Mankon to discuss the progress of the religion.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Cameroon Republic|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1978 | issn=0043-8804 | page =14 | url = | issue = 579}}</ref> Meanwhile, two individuals toured Cameroon in January; Hand of the Cause Rahmatu'llah Muhajir and Frenchman Armir Farhang-Imani each of whom who spoke to Bahá'í and public audiences.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Dr. Muhájir in Cameroon|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1975 | page =11 | url = | issue = 567}}</ref> Rahmatu'llah Muhajir again visited Cameroon as part of a broader trip through west Africa summer 1979.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; West Africa|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1980 | page =14 | url = | issue = 587 | issn=0195-9212}}</ref> Hand of the Cause [[Collis Featherstone]] visited Cameroon in February 1979.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Cameroon Republic |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1979 |issn=0043-8804 | page =17 | url = | issue = 581}}</ref> In 1980 simultaneous regional Bahá'í schools were held in March in English and French with about 25 people attending each.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Cameroon Republic |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=November 1980 |issn=0195-9212 | page =13 | url = | issue = 596}}</ref> A follow-up school was held in September at the end of which there was a wedding.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Cameroon Republic |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1981 |issn=0195-9212 | page =16 | url = | issue = 596}}</ref> In 1980 100 people including several national assembly members attended a national youth conference Yaounde.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Around the World; Cameroon Republic |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=January 1982 |issn=0195-9212 | page =13 | url = | issue = 610}}</ref> In 1982 a Bahá'í reached a remote region with pygmies and in three months was able convince 24 people to join the religion and another pioneer was moving to help him.<ref name="BN617" /> A pair of academic researchers toured west Africa from Switzerland speaking to the public and Bahá'ís in 1985.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = The World; Cameroon|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1984 |issn=0195-9212 | page =15 | url = | issue = 640}}</ref> They offered public talks "Women and Development" "How can woman assume her role in society?" and "Women and the Future of Mankind." and talks to Bahá'ís on "Excellence in All Things" and "Happiness in Marriage".<ref>{{cite magazine | title = The World; Cameroon Republic|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=December 1985 |issn=0195-9212 | page =15 | url = | issue = 657}}</ref>
====Tour of Hand of the Cause Rúhíyyih Khanum====
From January to March 1970 Rúhíyyih Khanum crossed Africa from east to west visiting many country's communities including Cameroon, meeting with individuals and institutions both Bahá'í and civic.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Hand of the Cause of God Rúhíyyih Khanum Travels Six Thousand Miles Across Africa |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1970 |pages=3–18 | url = | issue = 209}}</ref> In October 1971 Rúhíyyih Khanum returned from western Africa.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = The Great Safari of Hand of the Cause Ruhi; Part six; The Village of Ikotub |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1972 |pages=24–25 | url = | issue = 492}}</ref> She stopped for a time in Mamfe and spoke to the Bahá'ís there and emphasized the role of women in the growth of the religion.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = The Great Safari of Hand of the Cause Ruhi; Part seven; At Mamfe |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1972 | page =13 | url = | issue = 493}}</ref> From Mamfe she traveled more widely seeing villages and regional chiefs, attending weddings and giving talks at schools.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = The Great Safari of Hand of the Cause Ruhi; Part eight|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1972 |pages=12–16 | url = | issue = 493}}</ref> In many places she took note of women in prominent positions in the community and sometimes spoke to about the Bahá'í law of monogamy to contrast with the traditional cultural practice of polygamy and other traditional forms. A prominent meeting was of the regional conference calling for the progress of the religion in the region. She took part in the program of observances of United Nations Day sharing the stage with members of the staff of the Secretary-General of the UN as well as the staff of the Prime Minister of Cameroon.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Baha'i United Nations Reports |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1972 | page =10 | url = | issue = 491}}</ref> Reaching Buea she met with the Prime Minister and mentioned her wide travels in relative safety with kind assistance of villagers and truck drivers. From there she continued her travels through Douala and Yaounde and in each case also neighboring villages while also making time for radio interviews and at the University of Cameroon before moving on to Zaire.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = The Great Safari of Hand of the Cause Ruhi; Part nine |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=October 1972 |pages=8–11 | url = | issue = 498}}</ref>
====International Year of the Child====
Cameroon was one of the countries Bahá'í organized a series of events in honor of the [[International Year of the Child]], 1979.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = IYC report A worldwide round-up of Baha'i activities supporting the International Year of the Child (sections mentioning Cameroon) |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1980 |issn=0043-8804 |pages=6, 9 | url = | issue = 581}}</ref> Among the effort were articles in newspapers, tutorial schools in three cities, a women's conference in Liberia at which Cameroonians attended and radio interviews about the schools. There were women's and children's committees operating at a national level to sustain the teachers of the schools. A Bahá'í consultant traveled western Africa including Cameroon assisting communities in their efforts who was joined by volunteer from Canada who also traveled western Africa including Cameroon. And a Cameroonian woman, a headmistress of a nursery school volunteered to travel Cameroon encouraging projects and schools in the country.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Travels in Africa - The Baha'i International Community's consultant in Africa for IYC spends a busy 10 months on road |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=July 1980 |issn=0043-8804 |pages=10–15 | url = | issue = 581}}</ref>
====Commemorating pioneers====
Among those elected to the NSA was Ursula Samandari, who was elected to the institution in the years of 1972-74 and 1975–80, after being elected to the same institution in North East Africa and the British Isles. She had learned of the Bahá'í Faith from [[Richard St. Barbe Baker]] and [[Hasan M. Balyuzi]] in 1936. Among the comments at her 2003 funeral were these from the paramount chief of [[Buea]], HRH Samuel L. Endeley: <blockquote> "My dear Sister, You lived with us like one of us, you served faithfully and lovingly to win souls into God's redeeming grace. You loved us and our country, Cameroon, and you have demonstrated this in dying here like the good soldier of God you have lived to be. You died with your boots on. We thank God for all you were to us. May your soul rest with the good God, our creator, in perfect peace."<ref>{{Cite news | author = Bahá'í International Community| title = A love for all peoples | newspaper = Bahá'í World News Service | date = 2003-07-17 | url = http://news.bahai.org/story/230 }}</ref></blockquote>
Another member of the NSA who died unexpectedly was Karen Bare who had come from Hawaii in 1969. She was known for offering hospitality and also walking to villages for classes she taught and was elected as Secretary to the NSA for a time. She died in a car accident in 1974 while visiting family in the United States.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = In memoriam; Karen Bare |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=February 1974 | page =13 | url = | issue = 515}}</ref>
==Modern community==
By 2001 the National Spiritual Assembly was registered with the Government of Cameroon as one of the few non-Christian religions.<ref>{{Cite journal | author = Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor | title = Cameroon - International Religious Freedom Report | date = 2001-10-26 | publisher = U.S. State Department| url =https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2001/5587.htm }}</ref> Also in 2003 a project had begun to move the seat of the National Spiritual Assembly from Limbe, in the west, to the central capital, [[Yaoundé]], together with the responsibility to acquire a new National [[Haziratu'l-Quds|Bahá'í Centres]] for which the Bahá’í community of the United Kingdom has been asked to help.<ref name="uk" />
===Jubiliee===
Over 600 Bahá’ís and their friends gathered at the [[Convention center|Palais des congrès]] in Yaoundé to celebrate the Golden Jubilee of the founding of the Bahá'í community in Cameroon.<ref name="uk" /> Mr. and Mrs. Nakhjavani and other guests of honour, went to Limbe to visit the Bahá'í s of the southwest province, and Buea where they were received by the paramount chief, and travelled to Douala.
===Demographics===
In 2003 the Bahá'í community claimed 40,000 adherents and 58 Local Spiritual Assemblies,<ref name="bud" /> (there is another estimate from 2007-8 of more than 130,000 Bahá'is in Cameroon<ref>{{cite web | author = Religious Intelligence Ltd. | title = Country Profile: Cameroon (Republic of Cameroon)| work = Religious Intelligence | publisher = Religious Intelligence Ltd. | year = 2007–8| url =http://www.religiousintelligence.co.uk/country/?CountryID=119| accessdate = 2008-03-24|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012102156/http://www.religiousintelligence.co.uk/country/?CountryID=119|archivedate=October 12, 2007}}</ref> and another of members of the religion in 1744 localities in Cameroon.)<ref>{{cite book | title = Africa South of the Sahara 2004 | publisher = Routledge | year = 2003 | page = 180 | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=jj4J-AXGDaQC&pg=PA180&lpg=PA180 | isbn = 1-85743-183-9 | author1=Publications, Europa}}<!-- not found in reference | author = Taylor & Francis Group --></ref> However the [[Association of Religion Data Archives]] estimated there were some 50799 Bahá'ís in 2005.<ref name="WCE-05" />
===Multiplying interests===
Since its inception the religion has had involvement in [[Socio-economic development (Bahá'í)|socio-economic development]] beginning by giving greater freedom to women,<ref name="iranhistory">{{cite web | last = Momen | first = Moojan | title = History of the Baha'i Faith in Iran | work = draft "A Short Encyclopedia of the Baha'i Faith" | publisher = Bahai-library.com | date = | url = http://bahai-library.com/momen_encyclopedia_iran#9.%20Social%20and%20economic%20development | accessdate = 2009-10-16}}</ref> promulgating the promotion of female education as a priority concern,<ref>{{cite journal | last = Kingdon | first = Geeta Gandhi | title = Education of women and socio-economic development | journal = Baha'i Studies Review | volume = 7 | issue = 1 | year = 1997 | url =http://bahai-library.com/kingdon_education_women_development}}</ref> and that involvement was given practical expression by creating schools, agricultural coops, and clinics.<ref name="iranhistory" /> The religion entered a new phase of activity when a message of the [[Universal House of Justice]] dated 20 October 1983 was released.<ref>{{cite journal |title= The Baha'i Faith 1957–1988: A Survey of Contemporary Developments | first = Moojan | last = Momen |author2=Smith, Peter | year = 1989 | url = http://bahai-library.com/momen_smith_developments_1957-1988 |volume = 19 | journal = Religion | pages=63–91 |doi= 10.1016/0048-721X(89)90077-8}}</ref> Bahá'ís were urged to seek out ways, compatible with the [[Bahá'í teachings]], in which they could become involved in the social and economic development of the communities in which they lived. World-wide in 1979 there were 129 officially recognized Bahá'í socio-economic development projects. By 1987, the number of officially recognized development projects had increased to 1482. The Cameroonian community also became involved in a number of initiatives. In 1985 Bahá'ís established a tutorial school among the pygmies and the building infrastructure was to be expanded by the government now that a site had been developed.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Social/economic development; Number of projects growing rapidly|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1986 | page =2 | url = | issue = 660}}</ref> In 1990 the Cameroonian community held a nationwide campaign on the growth of the religion named in honor of Hand of the Cause Enoch Olinga with teams named after other Hands of the Cause.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = The World; Cameroon|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=March 1990 | page =17 | url = | issue = 707}}</ref>
====Involvement in advocacy for women====
The Cameroonian Bahá'í community has initiated and cooperated with a number of projects attempting to equalize the position of women, a primary [[Bahá'í teachings|principle]] of the religion. In 1985 a National Women's Committee of the Baha'is of Cameroon produced a statement "Equal Rights for Women and Men".<ref name="MacEoin" /> The rate at which women participated in December school of 1986 increased.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Special report - The International Year of Peace (section on Cameroon)|magazine= Bahá'í News |date=September 1987 | page =3 | url = | issue = 660}}</ref> The Bahá'ís of Cameroon cooperated with an initiative of the [[Bahá'í International Community]] in cooperation with [[UNIFEM]] on a project to effect a change in the social status of women in village communities in eastern Cameroon and other countries. The changes in the community focused on the role of women but aimed strongly at educating the men. According to Tiati Zock, the national coordinator of the project in Cameroon, a survey done in early 1992 among some 45 families in each of the seven villages reported that the men made virtually all of the financial decisions alone. A follow-up survey, taken in 1993, indicated more than 80 percent of the families now make such decisions in consultation between husband and wife. The number of girls being sent to one village school had increased by 82 percent by 1993.<ref>{{Cite news | author = Bahá'í International Community | title = UNIFEM/Bahá'í Project Raises Community Consciousness - By involving men in women's problems and using traditional media to communicate the results, grassroots changes are effected | periodical = One Country | issue = October–December | year = 1993| url = http://info.bahai.org/article-1-7-6-14.html }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Two Baha'i International Community Projects: Cameroon and Zambia |url=https://www.bic.org/statements/two-bahai-international-community-projects-cameroon-and-zambia |website=Bahá'í International Community}}</ref>
====Academic and civic forums====
The Bahá'í community of Cameroon has been involved in forums for wrestling with social issues in Cameroon in both academic and civic forums. In 1987 Cameroonian university students gathered in a conference from multiple tribes along with international students to facilitate an exchange of ideas on issues they all faced in society.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = The World; Cameroon |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=April 1988 | page =11 | url = | issue = 700}}</ref> This theme evolved in Yaoundé into the theme "African Youth Facing the Challenges of Modern Society" in 1988 and "The Role of Youth in a World in Search of Peace" in 1989.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Cameroon Republic |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=August 1989 | page =13 | url = | issue = 685}}</ref> Annual youth conferences in the northwest evolved and continued through 1990 and echoed many of these themes while also making efforts on other themes.<ref>{{cite magazine | title = Cameroon Republic |magazine= Bahá'í News |date=June 1990 | page =9 | issue = 710}}</ref> In 2002 the second Cameroon Bahá'í Academy took place at the Regional Bahá'í Centre at Yaoundé with 28 scholars from Buea, Douala, [[Dschang]], Soa, and Yaoundé. The key research paper, "Cameroonian Tribal and Family Meetings and the Bahá'í Teachings," was presented by Chongwain Nkuo, a teacher at the Post and Telecommunication School. It was published in the December 2002 volume of the Cameroon Bahá'í Studies journal. After his presentation there was an evaluation of his work by the members of a jury including David Nkwenti, Head of the Department of Anthropology of the [[University of Yaoundé]]. Nkwenti indicated he was going to expand academic interests in studying Bahá'í teachings and anthropological issues.<ref>{{Cite journal |first=Enoch N. |last=Tanyi |title=Cameroon |url=https://bahai-library.com/pdf/a/abs_bulletin82.pdf |journal=ABS Bulletin |number=82 |date=December 2003 |page=3 |publisher=Association for Bahá’í Studies - North America}}</ref> Also in 2002, for [[United Nations Day]] on October 24, members of the Buea religious community gathered for an interfaith panel discussion led by the Secretary General of the South West Province; the group included members or spokesmen of the Bahá'í Faith, the Muslim Imam, a representative of the Bishop of the Catholic Diocese, and a representative of the Hindu community.<ref>{{Cite news|author=Bahá'í International Community |title=Local Baha'is in Cameroon organize interfaith discussion for UN Day |newspaper=Bahá'í World News Service |date=2002-11-25 |url=http://www.upliftingwords.org/News/20021125Camaroon.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013213127/http://www.upliftingwords.org/News/20021125Camaroon.htm |archivedate=October 13, 2007 }}</ref> A January 20, 2007 service in Buea at the Bahá'í Centre of Learning commemorated [[World Religion Day]] among a similar breadth of representation.<ref>{{Cite news| last = Emmanuel | first = Mohmbah | title = Praying For Peace and Prosperity | newspaper = The Entrepreneur Newspaper | date = 2007-01-31 | url = http://www.entrepreneurnewsonline.com/2007/01/praying_for_pro_1.html}}</ref>
==See also==
* [[History of Cameroon]] * [[Freedom of religion in Cameroon]] * [[Bamileke]]
==Further reading==
{{Cite book | last = Lee | first = Anthony Asa | title = Dissertation: The establishment of the Baha'i Faith in West Africa: The first decade, 1952--1962 | publisher = University of California, Los Angeles | page = 371 | year = 2007 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=KbcjK-o8ff0C | isbn = 978-0-549-40690-7 }}

{{Infobox building | name = Bayterek Tower | native_name = {{lang-kk|Бәйтерек, Bäyterek}}
{{lang-ru|Байтерек}} | former_names = | alternate_names = Bayterek | image = Bayterek Tower.jpg | image_size = 256px | alt = | caption = Bayterek Tower | map_type = | altitude = |status = Complete | building_type = [[Monument]],
[[Observation tower]] | architectural_style = | structural_system = | cost = | ren_cost = | location = [[Astana]], [[Kazakhstan]] | address = | client = | owner = | current_tenants = | landlord = | coordinates = |start_date = October 25, 1996 |est_completion = |opening = | completion_date = August 30, 2002 | inauguration_date = | renovation_date = 2017 | demolition_date = | destruction_date = |antenna_spire = {{convert|105|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} |roof = |top_floor = {{convert|97|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} | height = | architect = | architecture_firm = | developer = | main_contractor = | structural_engineer = | services_engineer = | civil_engineer = | other_designers = | quantity_surveyor = | awards = | ren_architect = | ren_firm = | ren_str_engineer = | ren_serv_engineer = | ren_civ_engineer = | ren_oth_designers = | ren_qty_surveyor = | ren_awards = | references = }} '''Bayterek''' ([[Kazakh language|Kazakh]]: Бәйтерек, ''Bäyterek'', "tall [[Populus|poplar]] [tree]") is a monument and observation tower in [[Astana]], the capital city of [[Kazakhstan]]. A tourist attraction popular with foreign visitors and native Kazakhs, it is emblematic of the city, which became capital of the country in 1997. The tower is located within on the Nurzhol Boulevard, and is considered a symbol of post-independence Kazakhstan.{{cite book|url= |title=Kazakhstan |date=7 September 2018 |publisher=Bradt Travel Guides; Third edition |isbn=978-1784770921|pages= 92 |author1=Paul Brummell |author2=|deadurl=no|archiveurl= |archivedate=16 December 2017|df=dmy-all}} == Design == The monument is meant to embody a folktale about a mythical tree of life and a magic bird of happiness: the bird, named Samruk, had laid its [[egg (biology)|egg]] in the crevice between two branches of a poplar tree. The 105m (344.5 ft.) tall structure rises from a wide flat base within a raised plaza. It consists of a narrow cylindrical shaft, surrounded by white branch-like girders that flare out near the top, supporting a gold-mirrored 22 m diameter sphere. The base contains a ticket booth and exhibition space, with two lifts rising within the shaft to the observation deck within the 'egg'. Entrances to the monument are sunk below eye level, reached by stairs from the surrounding plaza. (It's somewhat similar to the [[1982 World's Fair]] Sunsphere in [[Knoxville, Tennessee|Knoxville, TN, USA]].(266 ft.) {{Citation needed|reason=This claim needs a reliable source; A passing similarity to an existing building does not mean the idea was copied|date=July 2017}} The observation deck is 97 m above ground level, corresponding to 1997, the year that Astana became the nation's capital. It consists of two levels, one with 360 degree views of Astana and beyond, with a second, higher level, reached by a flight of stairs. The top level features a gilded hand print of the right hand of [[Nursultan Nazarbayev]], the first President of the independent [[Republic of Kazakhstan]], mounted in an ornate pedestal. A plaque invites visitors to place a hand in the imprint and make a wish. Alongside the handprint, and also oriented in the direction of the presidential palace, is a wooden sculpture of a globe and 16 radiating segments, commemorating the Congress of Leaders of World and Traditional Religions, held several times in Astana. ==Photo gallery== File:Kazakhstani tenge 10000 (2006).jpg|The 10,000 Kazakhstani tenge note showing the image of the Bayterek tower File:View from Bayterek tower.jpg File:Bayterek monument.jpg|Bayterek tower ==See also== {{Commons category|Bayterek}} *[[Astana]] *[[Kazakhstan]] *[[History of Kazakhstan]] ==References== ==External links== * {{official website| http://www.astanahotels.ru/eng/astana/bayterek.htm Bayterek Monument}} *[https://abasayyoh.com/attractions/154 Bayterek Tower from "Abasayyoh"] {{coord|51.1283|N|71.4305|E|source:ruwiki_region:KZ_type:landmark|format=dms|display=title}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Astana]] [[Category:Towers in Kazakhstan]] [[Category:Norman Foster buildings]] [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 2002]] [[Category:Culture in Astana]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Astana]] [[Category:Towers completed in 2002]] [[Category:Observation towers in Astana]] [[Category:Landmarks in Kazakhstan]] [[Category:Perceptions of religious imagery in natural phenomena]] [[Category:2002 establishments in Kazakhstan]] {{kazakhstan-geo-stub}}

{{Infobox saint | name = Benoîte Rencurel | image = Notre-Dame-du-laus (sanctuaire - 7) - Portrait de Benoîte Rencurel.jpg | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | titles = Stigmatic, Marian visionary, Venerable | birth_name = | birth_date = 16 September 1647 | birth_place = [[Saint-Étienne-le-Laus]], [[France]] | home_town = | residence = | death_date = 25 December 1718 (aged 71) | death_place = | venerated_in = [[Roman Catholic Church]] | beatified_date = | beatified_place = | beatified_by = | canonized_date = | canonized_place = | canonized_by = | major_shrine = | feast_day = | attributes = | patronage = | issues = | suppressed_date = | suppressed_by = | influences = | influenced = | tradition = | major_works = }} {{Roman Catholic Mariology}} Venerable '''Benoîte (Benedicta) Rencurel''' (1647–1718) was a shepherdess from [[Saint-Étienne-le-Laus]], [[France]] who is said to have seen apparitions from the [[Virgin Mary]] from 1664 through 1718. The apparitions became known as [[Our Lady of Laus]], and the site receives thousands of pilgrim visits a year. On 4 May 2008, Bishop Jean-Michel di Falco of the Diocese of Gap officially recognized the apparitions of the Virgin Mary to Benoite Rencurel at the sanctuary of Laus in the area of Hautes-Alpes, France.<ref name=zenit>[http://www.zenit.org/article-22596?l=english "Church Approves French Marian Shrine", Zenit, May 15, 2008] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121007155330/http://www.zenit.org/article-22596?l=english |date=October 7, 2012 }}</ref>
==Life== Benoîte Rencurel was born on September 16, 1647, in the little town of Saint-Etienne d'Avançon, in the southern Alps. Her parents lived modestly from the works of their hands. Her father, Guillaume Rencurel, died when Benoîte was seven years old. For the widow and her daughters, his death would lead to material destitution. There was no school in Saint-Etienne d'Avançon, so Benoîte never learned to read or write.<ref name=clairval>[http://www.clairval.com/lettres/en/2003/07/31/2300703.htm Dom Antoine Marie osb. Abbey of Saint-Joseph de Clairval, 21 July 2003]</ref> At the age of twelve, she found work as a shepherdess.<ref>[http://catholictradition.org/Mary/laus.htm "Our Lady of Laus", Catholic Tradition]</ref>
In a homily during a Mass at the Marian basilica in the town of Laus, Archbishop Georges Pontier of Marseille, France, said that Rencurel had first seen Mary after being guided by a strange scent near her home in Saint-Etienne d'Avancon in May 1664 and later experienced a vision of Christ bleeding on the village cross.<ref name=cns>{{webarchive |url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20080513201121/http://www.catholicnews.com/data/stories/cns/0802498.htm |title="Church recognizes 17th-century Marian apparitions in France", Catholic News Service, May 6, 2008 |date=2008-05-13}}</ref>
During the apparitions, the Blessed Mother asked for a church and a house for priests to be built,<ref name=cns/> with the intention of drawing people to greater conversion, especially through the sacrament of penance. The holy site now draws 120,000 pilgrims annually. Numerous physical healings have also been associated with the site, especially when oil from a lamp is applied on the wounds according to the directives the Virgin Mary gave to Rencurel.<ref name=zenit/>
She became a Third Order Dominican and ministered to pilgrims and penitents as a lay Dominican tertiary in Laus.<ref name=cns/> She also urged women to be modest.<ref name=Mann>[https://www.osv.com/Magazines/TheCatholicAnswer/ByIssue/Article/TabId/809/ArtMID/13667/ArticleID/14360/Who-Is-Our-Lady-of-Laus-.aspx Mann, Stephanie A. "Who Is Our Lady of Laus?", ''Our Sunday Visitor'', March 28, 2014]</ref>
At the shrine in Laus, Benoite Rencurel is said to have had the gift of reading hearts. So many people came to ask her advice that she had to attend mass through a small window in the gallery of the Church to escape the crowds who sought to overwhelm her. She claimed to receive visions of Jesus in His passion from 1669 to 1679. She died on Christmas Day 1718.<ref name=Mann/>
The very modern message of Benoite, Bishop di Falco stated, is "to live heart to heart with God in prayer, enter deeper into conversion where we are reconciled with ourselves, with others and with God, and live your mission where your life is, in everyday community and joy."<ref name=zenit/>
She was bestowed the title ''Servant of God'' by [[Pope Pius IX]]. On 3 April 2009, Benedict XVI declared Benoite "Venerable".<ref>{{webarchive |url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20090416202104/http://www.catholicnews.com/data/stories/cns/0901526.htm |title=Wooden, Cindy,"Pope advances sainthood causes of 11, including Italian nun", Catholic News Service, April 3, 2009 |date=2009-04-16}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Biography|Catholicism|France}}
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.sanctuaire-notredamedulaus.com/ Sanctuary of Laus — official website] *[http://www.ewtn.com/series/shows/forgottenHeritage/forgottenHeritageEpisode.asp ''Forgotten Heritage'', Episode 4, "Laus, France: Sacrament of Penance"]
